title: Extremal Number
content:
**The Extremal Number** ex(n; H):

The maximum number of edges in an n-vertex graph containing no copy of H.

**Properties:**
- Monotonic in n: more vertices allows more edges
- Trivially bounded by n(n-1)/2 (complete graph)

Axiomatized since computing requires quantification over all n-vertex graphs.
mathContext: Central to extremal graph theory, initiated by Turán (1941).

title: Extremal Monotonicity
content:
**ex(n; H) ≤ ex(m; H) for n ≤ m**

More vertices allows at least as many edges while avoiding H.

Proof: Any H-free graph on n vertices can be extended to m vertices with isolated vertices.

title: Graph Degeneracy
content:
**k-Degeneracy Definition:**

A graph G is k-degenerate if every non-empty induced subgraph has a vertex of degree at most k.

**Equivalent characterizations:**
1. Vertices can be ordered so each has ≤ k neighbors among predecessors
2. The graph has arboricity at most k
3. Every subgraph has average degree < 2k

Axiomatized for graphs encoded as natural numbers.
mathContext: Degeneracy measures structural sparsity. Trees are 1-degenerate, planar graphs are 5-degenerate.

title: 2-Degenerate Characterization
content:
**2-Degenerate means:**

No induced subgraph has minimum degree ≥ 3.

Equivalently: every subgraph has a vertex of degree at most 2.

**Examples:**
- Paths and cycles are 2-degenerate
- Outerplanar graphs are 2-degenerate
- K_4 is NOT 2-degenerate (min degree 3)

title: Bipartite Graphs
content:
**Bipartite Graphs:**

A graph G is bipartite if its vertices can be partitioned into two sets A, B such that every edge connects a vertex in A to one in B.

**Equivalent:** G has no odd cycles.

Axiomatized as a predicate on encoded graphs.

title: Complete Bipartite Encoding
content:
**K_{s,t} Encoding:**

The complete bipartite graph K_{s,t} is encoded as s * 1000 + t.

This allows referencing specific complete bipartite graphs in axioms about extremal numbers.

**Example:** K_{2,3} is encoded as 2003.

title: Kővári-Sós-Turán Theorem
content:
**KST Theorem (1954):**

ex(n; K_{s,t}) ≤ (1/2)(t-1)^{1/s} · n^{2-1/s} + (s-1)n/2

for t ≥ s ≥ 1.

**Significance:** This is the fundamental upper bound for forbidden bipartite subgraphs.

**Special cases:**
- K_{2,2} = C_4: ex(n; C_4) = O(n^{3/2})
- K_{3,3}: ex(n; K_{3,3}) = O(n^{5/3})
mathContext: The proof uses double counting: count paths of length s, then apply convexity.

title: C_4 Extremal Number
content:
**ex(n; C_4) = O(n^{3/2})**

The 4-cycle C_4 = K_{2,2} has extremal number O(n^{3/2}).

This is the threshold exponent in the Erdős-Simonovits conjecture.

**Tight:** There exist graphs achieving Ω(n^{3/2}) edges.

title: Asymptotic Notation
content:
**f ≪ g means f = O(g)**

Formally: ∃ C > 0, ∃ n₀, ∀ n ≥ n₀: f(n) ≤ C · g(n)

This is the standard big-O notation adapted for use in Lean.

The notation has precedence 50, requiring parentheses with → and ↔.

title: Asymptotic Transitivity
content:
**If f ≪ n^α and α < β, then f ≪ n^β**

This captures that O(n^{4/3}) ⊆ O(n^{3/2}) when 4/3 < 3/2.

Essential for the Janzer counterexample argument.

title: Erdős-Simonovits Conjecture
content:
**The Conjecture (1984):**

For bipartite G:
  ex(n; G) ≪ n^{3/2} ⟺ G is 2-degenerate

**Forward Direction (TRUE):**
If G is 2-degenerate bipartite, then ex(n;G) ≪ n^{3/2}.

**Backward Direction (DISPROVED):**
If ex(n;G) ≪ n^{3/2}, then G is 2-degenerate.

The conjecture claims both directions hold. Janzer disproved the backward direction.
mathContext: Conjectured in 'Cube-supersaturated graphs and related problems' (1984).

title: Forward Direction
content:
**Forward Direction is TRUE:**

If G is bipartite and 2-degenerate, then ex(n;G) ≪ n^{3/2}.

The proof follows from the KST theorem and properties of 2-degenerate graphs.

This half of the conjecture was never in doubt.

title: Backward Direction (Disproved)
content:
**Backward Direction is FALSE:**

∃ bipartite G: ex(n;G) ≪ n^{3/2} ∧ G is NOT 2-degenerate

Janzer (2023) constructed such a counterexample.

This axiom encapsulates Janzer's disproof.

title: Regular Graphs
content:
**k-Regular Graphs:**

A graph is k-regular if every vertex has exactly degree k.

Axiomatized as a predicate isRegular(g, k).

**Key fact:** 3-regular graphs are NOT 2-degenerate.

title: 3-Regular Not 2-Degenerate
content:
**3-Regular ⟹ NOT 2-Degenerate**

If G is 3-regular, then every vertex has degree 3.

Thus every induced subgraph on G has minimum degree at least 3 (for the whole graph) or contains a vertex of degree 3.

This contradicts 2-degeneracy.
mathContext: This is the key structural property exploited by Janzer.

title: Janzer's Theorem
content:
**Janzer's Theorem (2023):**

For any ε > 0, there exists a 3-regular bipartite graph H such that
  ex(n; H) ≪ n^{4/3 + ε}

**Significance:**
- H is 3-regular, hence NOT 2-degenerate
- But ex(n; H) ≪ n^{4/3 + ε} ≪ n^{3/2}

This directly disproves the backward direction of the conjecture.
mathContext: The construction uses subdivision methods from extremal combinatorics.

title: Janzer Beats Threshold
Füredi's Theorem
content:
**Füredi's Theorem (1996):**

Tight bounds for ex(n; K_{s,t}) when t is large relative to s.

There exist constants c₁, c₂ > 0 such that:
  c₁ · n^{2-1/s} ≤ ex(n; K_{s,t}) ≤ c₂ · n^{2-1/s}

This shows the KST bound is essentially optimal.

title: Related Erdős Problems
content:
**Related Problems:**

**#146 (Zarankiewicz):** Exact values of ex(n; K_{s,t})

**#147 (Turán Exponents):** For bipartite G, ∃ r ∈ [1,2] with ex(n;G) ≪ n^r

These problems study the same extremal phenomena from different angles.

title: Main Result: Conjecture Disproved
content:
**erdos_113: ¬ErdosSimonovitsConjecture**

**Proof:**
1. Assume ErdosSimonovitsConjecture holds
2. Apply backward_false to get counterexample g:
   - g is bipartite
   - ex(n;g) ≪ n^{3/2}
   - g is NOT 2-degenerate
3. By the conjecture's ↔, ex ≪ n^{3/2} implies 2-degenerate
4. But g is NOT 2-degenerate — contradiction
5. Therefore the conjecture is FALSE.

**The $500 prize was claimed by Janzer.**

title: Forward Direction Theorem
content:
**erdos_113_forward:**

isBipartite g → isDegenerate g 2 → ex(n;g) ≪ n^{3/2}

This theorem confirms the forward direction remains true.

The conjecture was only half wrong.
